title: Chapter 7 with a reverse mortgage (HECM)
question: I have a client who has a reverse mortgage but is planning to declare Chapter 7 bankruptcy. How does this work? Will she lose her home? She is currently looking for a bankruptcy attorney and lives in Playa del Ray.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Debt,Mortgage lien,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Home mortgage
answers:
We would need to know:

1. FMV of home
2. Debts secured by property.
3. Age of client.
4. Income of client
5. Is client disabled in any way

These are all factors that are used to determine what the homestead exemption should be.

It is best to consult a good BK lawyer on this issue.

BW

She should meet w/ an experienced BK atty. The key issue is the amount of equity in the property, as well as her age. Depending on all the facts, she may be able to keep as much as $175,000 of equity.

If you are tying to help her search for an attorney, you may want to use the "Find a Lawyer" search feature. It is unlikely that any attorney in your community will see this post and respond.

Hope this perspective helps!

She will only lose the home to the extent that their is equity in the property that exceeds any exemptions allowed. The property is an asset of the estate and the reverse mortgage lien will survive the bankruptcy.
